context: Several commemorative events take place every year. Gatherings of <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>thousands<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> of people on the banks of the Vistula on <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b7_0>Midsummer’s Night<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> for a festival called <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>Wianki<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> (Polish for Wreaths) have become a tradition and a yearly event in the programme of cultural events in Warsaw. The festival traces its roots to a peaceful pagan ritual where maidens would float their wreaths of herbs on the water to predict <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>when they would be married<b8_0/><a3_0/>,<a3_2/> and to whom<a3_1/>. By the 19th century this tradition had become a festive event, and it continues today. The city council organize concerts and other events. Each Midsummer’s Eve, apart from the official floating of wreaths, jumping over fires, looking for <a4_0><b9_0>the <a4_1><a4_2>fern<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> flower, there are musical performances, dignitaries' speeches, fairs and fireworks by the river bank.
